image.altText: Stills of video which played a role in the Australian's four month investigation

items.synopsis: A senior lawyer and two First Nations executives have been appointed to review the APY Art Centre Collective (APYACC), following allegations of interference in Aboriginal art.

title.children: Panel appointed to review APY Art Centre Collective following allegations of interference

image.altText: A man in a wheelchair with his service dog standing with its paws on his lap

items.synopsis: A lack of legislation requiring local governments to provide public toilets means some areas are neglected, a researcher says.

title.children: Disability advocate calls for urgent action to address public bathroom shortage

image.altText: An illustration of a woman crouched on a hospital bed with her head in her arms

items.synopsis: Too many women are leaving mental health units in a worse condition than when they arrived, with some in mixed-gender wards reporting shocking treatment that has left them reluctant to seek further care.

title.children: Casey turned to a mental health facility for help after her assault. She left in a worse state than when she arrived

image.altText: Australia captain Pat Cummins gives the thumbs-up during a rain delay in the Ashes Test at Old Trafford.

items.synopsis: Australia will carry a 2-1 lead into the final Test of the Ashes series in England, meaning they have retained the Urn on the back of a drawn fourth game at Old Trafford with a little help from the rain that washed out day five.

title.children: Australia retains the Ashes in anti-climactic fashion as rain wipes out final day of fourth Test

image.altText: Iceberg in the Southern Ocean, seen from a ship.

items.synopsis: Antarctic sea ice has usually been able to recover in winter. But this time it's different, with levels taking a sharp downward turn at a time of year when sea ice usually forms reliably — and experts are worried.

title.children: A once in every 7.5 million year event is unfolding in the Antarctic. And it has scientists scrambling for answers

image.altText: Craig Reucassel in a high vis orange vest and hard hat and standing in front of a pile of plastic bottles at a recycling plant

items.synopsis: Australia, we're still in a war with waste, and while not all of the solutions rest with households, there’s still plenty we can do at home to reduce our waste footprint.

title.children: Australian households throw out an average $2,500 in food every year. Here’s how you can start reducing your waste

image.altText: A mother sits on a black leather couch with her arms around her two young children.

items.synopsis: This refugee mother has waited for more than a decade to be reunited with her older children. Learning she'll have to wait a few more years has been devastating.

title.children: 'I need my children': Susan has spent 11 years fighting to be reunited with her two older children

image.altText: An aerial photo showing a Navy ship in the open ocean, with a military jet flying overhead.

items.synopsis: An aerial photograph obtained by the ABC shows an RAAF P-8 Poseidon plane flying over a Chinese surveillance ship as it headed towards Australia last week.

title.children: First image emerges of Australia's encounter with Chinese spy ship

image.altText: A close-up of a man with white hair with a serious expression

items.synopsis: An Adelaide grandfather says an ongoing wait for a public hospital appointment to learn whether or not he has bowel cancer has caused him so much stress he now sees a psychologist.

title.children: 'I've got a lot of living to do': Lengthy wait for cancer diagnosis causing grandfather stress

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus puimps her left fist after claiming world championships gold.

items.synopsis: Ariarne Titmus produces a breathtaking performance at the World Aquatics Championships, while Australia sets a new global mark in the women's 4x100m freestyle relay and creates history by winning a staggering four gold medals on the opening night of swimming finals.

title.children: 'Fearless' Titmus breaks world record as Australia enjoys golden night in Fukuoka

image.altText: Pat Cummins smiles while walking out of the Australian dressing room with Usman Khawaja

items.synopsis: The rain played its part in getting Australia home at Old Trafford, but despite dissenting voices from England, this is a triumph fully deserved by Pat Cummins's side, set up by some wonderful cricket.

title.children: Australia's rain-soaked Ashes retention still worthy of celebration, but now it's time to win them

image.altText: A graphic showing an unidentified woman, an HIV ribbon, a visa form and stamp that says 'denied'

items.synopsis: Australia is one of only around 40 countries with visa restrictions for people living with HIV. Advocates want that to end.

title.children: Debbie's HIV status kept her from getting permanent residency. So she took on the government — and won

image.altText: A woman reads.

items.synopsis: Adelaide theatre company ActNow Theatre is touring South Australian schools with interpretive anti-racism workshops drawing from personal experiences. And one school says it's having a dramatic impact on discrimination.

title.children: Theatre company director uses racism experiences to spread message of 'respect for everyone'

image.altText: A male, caucasian politican speakking at a press conference, infron of blank curtains and flags

items.synopsis: The government says new changes would closes a legal "loophole", offering more than 850,000 casuals who work regular hours a new pathway to permanent work.

title.children: Government to close loophole allowing employers to treat casual workers like permanent employees without benefits

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is making small gains to start the week, but all eyes will be on the local inflation data out on Wednesday. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX edges up as traders nervously await inflation data

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As flagged by the futures market, the ASX is eking out the most modest of gains in early trade. The ASX 200 index was up just 0.1% in the first half hour to 7,321 points and the All Ords up just 6 points to 7,532. This morning's best gains have come from the energy sector, with a couple of coal miners in the top ten — Whitehaven (+2.3%) and New Hope (+1.9%). The tech sector was also up, with WiseTech Global (+1.7%) and REA Group (+1.4%) amongst the biggest gains. The financial sector continued to edge higher (+0.2%) with all four major banks posting modest gains. But the large mining sector weighed on the ASX, with BHP and Rio Tinto broadly flat, and suppliers of commodities needed for batteries, such as lithium and nickel, generally getting pummeled. Core Lithium had dropped 13.2%, with Sayona Mining and Lake Resources down 5.9%, Liontown down 4.6% and Pilbara Minerals off 4.3%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens barely higher

and the

Core Lithium had dropped 13.2%, with Sayona Mining and Lake Resources down 5.9%, Liontown down 4.6% and Pilbara Minerals off 4.3%.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: No sugar coating this one — today looks set to be fairly quiet for share price action overall as investors await more info. The key bit locally is the June quarter Consumer Price Index, to be released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday at 11:30am AEST. Economists are typically expecting the headline number to fall to 6.2%, with the RBA's preferred 'trimmed mean' measure of inflation easing to 6%, according to a Refinitiv survey. The consensus is broadly that a number much above those levels will all but guarantee another interest rate hike on August 1, while a number in line with or below those forecasts is more likely to see the RBA stay on hold at a 4.1% cash rate. A rise in rates would be bad for many stocks — it lifts the valuation benchmark for one thing, but also increases the prospect of an Australian recession, which is not great for the earnings outlook. Ahead of those key numbers (which I'll have more about shortly) the ASX SPI 200 futures are up 0.4% to 7,300 points. That followed a quiet Friday session on Wall Street, where the Dow Jone Industrial Average and S & P 500 were almost dead flat, and the Nasdaq down just slightly. I suggest grabbing a coffee, or another one, because you might need it to get through what could be quite a dull day on the markets.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shares set for subdued start as inflation data awaited

children.content: No sugar coating this one — today looks set to be fairly quiet for share price action overall as investors await more info.
The key bit locally is the June quarter Consumer Price Index, to be released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday at 11:30am AEST.
Economists are typically expecting the headline number to fall to 6.2%, with the RBA's preferred 'trimmed mean' measure of inflation easing to 6%, according to a Refinitiv survey.

The consensus is broadly that a number much above those levels will all but guarantee another interest rate hike on August 1, while a number in line with or below those forecasts is more likely to see the RBA stay on hold at a 4.1% cash rate.
A rise in rates would be bad for many stocks — it lifts the valuation benchmark for one thing, but also increases the prospect of an Australian recession, which is not great for the earnings outlook.
Ahead of those key numbers (which I'll have more about shortly) the ASX SPI 200 futures are up 0.4% to 7,300 points.
That followed a quiet Friday session on Wall Street, where the Dow Jone Industrial Average and S
P 500 were almost dead flat, and the Nasdaq down just slightly.
I suggest grabbing a coffee, or another one, because you might need it to get through what could be quite a dull day on the markets.

image.altText: A man in military dress and a woman in a pink suit and hat

items.synopsis: Juan Carlos was once a handsome young king who saved Spain from tyranny. Now disgraced and living in exile, his son Felipe dreads his potential return.

title.children: 'Always embarrassed by his father': Why Spain's King Felipe is dreading his disgraced dad's return

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin's face is illuminated by a streetlight as he partially smiles through the window of a car, rolled down

items.synopsis: Russia has long been a "paramilitarised" regime, where the state can be challenged and undermined by paramilitary or criminal groups but not completely destroyed, writes Mark Edele.

title.children: Has Putin contained the Prigozhin and Wagner threat?

image.altText: A waist-down photo of a person who is wearing a uniform carrying a big leather bag in each hand

items.synopsis: The heavy black bag carried by military aides who follow closely in the president's footsteps has been shrouded in secrecy for decades. Little is known about the contents of the bag, as most documents about it remain classified, but one nuclear war researcher has dug deep into its history.

title.children: The 'nuclear football' follows the US president everywhere. Here's the story behind it

image.altText: A man walks in a heavily damaged cathedral

items.synopsis: A Russian missile attack on Ukraine's southern port of Odesa kills one, injures 20 and severely damages an Orthodox cathedral in the city centre, a UNESCO world heritage site, according to President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

title.children: World heritage-listed cathedral badly damaged in Russian missile strikes on Odesa

image.altText: a woman standing inside an aged care centre looking at the camera

items.synopsis: The sector warns delays in reimbursing providers has created a "perfect storm" in which more than half of aged care homes are operating at a loss.

title.children: Aged care providers carrying estimated half a billion dollars in debt as they await promised COVID grants

image.altText: A solomon islander looking back at the camera with a pensive expression

items.synopsis: Gina Kekea was a young reporter at Solomon Islands national broadcaster when militants stormed the studio. Now, 20 years on, she hopes lessons have been learnt as her country faces an uncertain future.

title.children: It was a time when armed militants roamed the streets. Then Australian troops came and took the guns away

image.altText: A scene of a collapsed building with an excavator digging through rubble as people watch

items.synopsis: Authorities say the number of casualties could be higher as rescuers dig through the rubble in the city of Douala.

title.children: Cameroon building collapse kills at least 16 people

image.altText: A young Indigenous woman close up portrait

items.synopsis: Experts say boosting the number of Indigenous midwives will help to prevent birth trauma experienced by First Nations parents.

title.children: Calls for more Indigenous midwives to make giving birth a less 'disorienting' and 'traumatic' experience for First Nations people

image.altText: Players fight for a header.

items.synopsis: One of the tournament favourites France were unable to get their World Cup off to a winning start, drawing a feisty and physical match with Jamaica 0-0.

title.children: Jamaica earns famous draw with France after Sweden denies South Africa their own historic moment

image.altText: Dr Daniel Lanzer gestures with his hands while talking on the set of a tv show. He is wearing a surgeon's scrubs.

items.synopsis: Deformities, nerve damage, psychological trauma, loss of function of limbs. It's quite the list of allegations in what is shaping up as one of Australia's biggest-ever cosmetic surgery class actions, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: A nip and tuck, not a full facelift: Whistleblower fears changes to cosmetic surgery regulations don't go far enough

image.altText: A male figure in a t-shirt holds out a clear glass jar half filled with Australian bank notes and coins.

items.synopsis: If you received a tax bill this year you will most likely have to pay your debt but there is help available for those who are struggling financially.

title.children: Why am I getting a bill from the ATO this tax time?

image.altText: A photo of missing teenager Rose Howell, c. 2003.

items.synopsis: Rose Howell, then 18, was last seen walking along a road south of Coffs Harbour on a Friday evening in 2003.

title.children: Police offer $750,000 reward for teen who disappeared 20 years ago, days before her birthday

image.altText: An F1 driver wearing a black shirt and orange hat looks into the distance.

items.synopsis: The Melbourne-born McLaren driver finished fifth in Sunday's Hungarian Grand Prix.

title.children: Oscar Piastri praised by McLaren boss after finishing fifth in Hungary

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit pushes his fingertips together onstage in front of a black and white backdrop.

items.synopsis: Twitter owner Elon Musk announces a name change for Twitter as chief executive Linda Yaccarino says the company is looking forward to bringing X to the world.

title.children: Twitter to rebrand to X and drop blue bird, Musk says

image.altText: a young brunette woman with two little girls whose faces are blurred

items.synopsis: Three people — a 25-year-old woman, a 65-year-old man and a 38-year-old woman — were killed in Friday's crash on the Bruce Highway.

title.children: Family of young mum killed in triple fatal crash south of Gympie say man who helped her 'deserves a medal'

image.altText: A blond woman taking a selfie outside with a bearded man next to her and two girls climbing on their back above them

items.synopsis: Influenza case numbers are soaring around the country, with young people and children the hardest hit. Some experts say it is time to make better of use of antivirals.

title.children: 'Simply too late': Flu season is so bad this year some experts are calling for more antiviral use

image.altText: A street with multiple yellow and green ambulances and police cars infront of a building under construction

items.synopsis: Solomona Tootoo, 45, and Tupuga Sipiliano, 44, both worked on the CBD construction site where a 24-year-old gunman opened fire early on Thursday morning. Police believe the offender, now dead, previously also worked at the site.

title.children: NZ police name victims of Auckland shooting

image.altText: Arisa Trew upside down on a skateboard.

items.synopsis: Chloe Covell and Arisa Trew break records at the 2023 X Games in California.

title.children: Thirteen-year-old Aussie skating prodigies win gold at X Games

image.altText: Tourists walk along a stony road in Rhodes as the sky behind them is filled with wildfire smoke

items.synopsis: Coastguard vessels and private boats evacuate thousands of people, including tourists, from beaches on the south-eastern part of the island, with people in nearby villages also warned to leave as flames approached.

title.children: Wildfire on Greek island of Rhodes forces mass evacuations, as tourists attempt to leave
